vrPpTbclRowStatusTable.name: vrPpTbclRowStatusTable
vrPpTbclRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of vrPpTbcl components.

vrPpTbclRowStatusEntry.name: vrPpTbclRowStatusEntry
vrPpTbclRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single vrPpTbcl component.

vrPpTbclRowStatus.name: vrPpTbclRowStatus
vrPpTbclRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of vrPpTbcl components. These components can be added and deleted.

vrPpTbclComponentName.name: vrPpTbclComponentName
vrPpTbclComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

vrPpTbclStorageType.name: vrPpTbclStorageType
vrPpTbclStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the vrPpTbcl tables.

vrPpTbclIndex.name: vrPpTbclIndex
vrPpTbclIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the vrPpTbcl tables.

vrPpTbclProvTable.name: vrPpTbclProvTable
vrPpTbclProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

vrPpTbclTranslateIpx.name: vrPpTbclTranslateIpx
vrPpTbclTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

vrPpTbclFragmentIp.name: vrPpTbclFragmentIp
vrPpTbclFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

vrPpTbclServiceClass.name: vrPpTbclServiceClass
vrPpTbclServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

vrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress.name: vrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress
vrPpTbclConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

vrPpTbclPortNum.name: vrPpTbclPortNum
vrPpTbclPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

vrPpTbclOutboundFrameMediaType.name: vrPpTbclOutboundFrameMediaType
vrPpTbclOutboundFrameMediaType.description: This attribute specifies the media type the frame must be in before it is to be forwarded over the outbound supported WAN Bridge Protocol Port. The attribute only applies to outbound Bridge Protocol Port. For supported bridge ports, if the attribute value remains set to the default value of unaltered then there will be no frame conversion. When the value is set to the value ethernetConv then all frames being forwarded out the outbound WAN Port will be converted to ethernet before forwarding takes place. The only outbound WAN medias that currently support conversion are: FR (Frame Relay) and VNS. All other medias will fail the Bridge Port semantic check when attempts are made to alter this attribute. The following is an example of what the user may be able to do. Frames originating from a Token Ring are to be flooded out onto another Token Ring and a Frame Relay Port. The token ring Outbound port performs no translation, yet the FR Port has the outboundFrameMediaType attribute set to ethernetConv which results in the frame being translated into Ethernet format from Token Ring format before Frame Relay does its encapsulation and transmits over the FR port.

vrPpTbclTbProvTable.name: vrPpTbclTbProvTable
vrPpTbclTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

vrPpTbclSecureOption.name: vrPpTbclSecureOption
vrPpTbclSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

vrPpTbclStpProvTable.name: vrPpTbclStpProvTable
vrPpTbclStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

vrPpTbclAdminStatus.name: vrPpTbclAdminStatus
vrPpTbclAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

vrPpTbclPortStateStpControl.name: vrPpTbclPortStateStpControl
vrPpTbclPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

vrPpTbclStpTypeProv.name: vrPpTbclStpTypeProv
vrPpTbclStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

vrPpTbclPortPriority.name: vrPpTbclPortPriority
vrPpTbclPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

vrPpTbclPathCost.name: vrPpTbclPathCost
vrPpTbclPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

vrPpTbclPathCostMethod.name: vrPpTbclPathCostMethod
vrPpTbclPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

vrPpTbclDIProvTable.name: vrPpTbclDIProvTable
vrPpTbclDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

vrPpTbclDomainNum.name: vrPpTbclDomainNum
vrPpTbclDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

vrPpTbclPreserveDomain.name: vrPpTbclPreserveDomain
vrPpTbclPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

vrPpTbclStateTable.name: vrPpTbclStateTable
vrPpTbclStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

vrPpTbclAdminState.name: vrPpTbclAdminState
vrPpTbclAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

vrPpTbclOperationalState.name: vrPpTbclOperationalState
vrPpTbclOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

vrPpTbclUsageState.name: vrPpTbclUsageState
vrPpTbclUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

vrPpTbclOperStatusTable.name: vrPpTbclOperStatusTable
vrPpTbclOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

vrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus.name: vrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus
vrPpTbclSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

vrPpTbclOperTable.name: vrPpTbclOperTable
vrPpTbclOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

vrPpTbclPortName.name: vrPpTbclPortName
vrPpTbclPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

vrPpTbclUpTime.name: vrPpTbclUpTime
vrPpTbclUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpTbclDownTime.name: vrPpTbclDownTime
vrPpTbclDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpTbclBridgingMode.name: vrPpTbclBridgingMode
vrPpTbclBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

vrPpTbclBridgePortConfig.name: vrPpTbclBridgePortConfig
vrPpTbclBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

vrPpTbclBridgePortType.name: vrPpTbclBridgePortType
vrPpTbclBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

vrPpTbclIfIndex.name: vrPpTbclIfIndex
vrPpTbclIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

vrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards.name: vrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards
vrPpTbclDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

vrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards.name: vrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards
vrPpTbclMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

vrPpTbclTbOperTable.name: vrPpTbclTbOperTable
vrPpTbclTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

vrPpTbclMaxInfo.name: vrPpTbclMaxInfo
vrPpTbclMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

vrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards.name: vrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards
vrPpTbclBadVerifyDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because: a) the value of the secureOption attribute was set to on and b) it is not allowed to receive frames originating from the mac address found in the source address field of the frame (source mac address look up in the forwarding table failed.) on this bridge port. c) for the destination mac address found in the frame, the port the frame was received on does not appear as in port in the corresponding static table entry. Permission to receive frames from a mac address is granted via the static table entries. This attribute, badVerifyDiscards, is directly influenced by: 1. secureOption and 2. the static table entries. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches.name: vrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches
vrPpTbclUnicastNoMatches.description: This attribute is indicative of the number frames discarded because the MAC address found in the destination field did not match the local MAC address of the bridge port. This counter is only applicable for the protocols that are being routed currently.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards.name: vrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards
vrPpTbclStaticEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because of the following two reasons: a) there was no entry for the 'allowed to go' field in the static table entry, where the input port is this bridge port. b) for spanning tree bpdus that are locally processed. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. It might prove useful to check the static table entry corresponding to the bridge port in question, if this counter consistently displays a high value. Ideally this counter should be as low as possible.

vrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards.name: vrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards
vrPpTbclDynamicEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that a) were discarded because of the fact that the bridge port, the frame is to go out of matches the bridge port it came in from or b) if the stp port state of the out port is not forwarding. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclLearningDiscards.name: vrPpTbclLearningDiscards
vrPpTbclLearningDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded while this bridge port was in a state other than the forwarding state. While in learning state the frame is discarded after the information from its header is learnt. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclInDiscards.name: vrPpTbclInDiscards
vrPpTbclInDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were received by this bridge port and were discarded by the forwarding process. This includes frames that could have been discarded due to filtering. A repidly increasing value for this attribute could indicate a shrtage of resource in terms of memory needed to process the incoming frames. More memory can be provisioned through the VirtualRouter's memory manager.

vrPpTbclInFrames.name: vrPpTbclInFrames
vrPpTbclInFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been received by this port from its segment. Note that a frame received on this bridge port is counted if and only if it can be processed by the bridge logic contained in this bridge unit, a protocol that can be processed by the bridge logic. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclOutFrames.name: vrPpTbclOutFrames
vrPpTbclOutFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been transmitted out this bridge port. Note that frame transmitted out this bridge port is counted if and only if it is for a protocol being processed by the bridge unit. This also includes management frames.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclStpOperTable.name: vrPpTbclStpOperTable
vrPpTbclStpOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes reflect the state of the bridge port's participation in the spanning tree protocol.

vrPpTbclStpPortState.name: vrPpTbclStpPortState
vrPpTbclStpPortState.description: This attribute specifies the spanning tree protocol state of the bridge port.

vrPpTbclStpTypeOper.name: vrPpTbclStpTypeOper
vrPpTbclStpTypeOper.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol.

vrPpTbclDesignatedCost.name: vrPpTbclDesignatedCost
vrPpTbclDesignatedCost.description: This attribute specifies the path cost of the designated port of the lan segment connected to the port.

vrPpTbclPathCostOper.name: vrPpTbclPathCostOper
vrPpTbclPathCostOper.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. This attribute pathCostOper will track the value of the attribute pathCostProv when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set of off.

vrPpTbclDesignatedBridge.name: vrPpTbclDesignatedBridge
vrPpTbclDesignatedBridge.description: This attribute specifies the identifier of the bridge that this port considers to be the designated bridge.

vrPpTbclDesignatedPort.name: vrPpTbclDesignatedPort
vrPpTbclDesignatedPort.description: This attribute specifies the port identifier of the port on the designated bridge, attached to the same lan as this port is attached to.

vrPpTbclForwardTransitions.name: vrPpTbclForwardTransitions
vrPpTbclForwardTransitions.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of times this bridge port transitioned from the learning state to the forwarding state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. A rapidly increasing value might be indicative of an unstable spanning tree topology.

vrPpTbclBlockingDiscards.name: vrPpTbclBlockingDiscards
vrPpTbclBlockingDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because the bridge port was in the blocking state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclDesignatedRoot.name: vrPpTbclDesignatedRoot
vrPpTbclDesignatedRoot.description: This attribute specifies the bridge identifier of the bridge recorded as the root bridge, in the configuration BPDUs sent out by the designated bridge on the segment to which the port is attached.

vrPpTbclStatsTable.name: vrPpTbclStatsTable
vrPpTbclStatsTable.description: This group houses all the statistical attributes applicable to all types of bridge ports and represents the common factor between them. These attributes in part reflect the state of the bridge port.

vrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards.name: vrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards
vrPpTbclBadAbstractDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the data that was abstracted, from frames coming in through this bridge port, did not conform to the format expected by the bridge logic.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn.name: vrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn
vrPpTbclTinygramFramesIn.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames received on this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

vrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut.name: vrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut
vrPpTbclTinygramFramesOut.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames transmitted out this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

vrPpTbclInFilterDiscards.name: vrPpTbclInFilterDiscards
vrPpTbclInFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the in filter point. This includes a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the in filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the in filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards.name: vrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards
vrPpTbclOutFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the out filter point. This includes: a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the out filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the out filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable.name: vrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable
vrPpTbclNsRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of vrPpTbclNs components.

vrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry.name: vrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry
vrPpTbclNsRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single vrPpTbclNs component.

vrPpTbclNsRowStatus.name: vrPpTbclNsRowStatus
vrPpTbclNsRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of vrPpTbclNs components. These components can be added and deleted.

vrPpTbclNsComponentName.name: vrPpTbclNsComponentName
vrPpTbclNsComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

vrPpTbclNsStorageType.name: vrPpTbclNsStorageType
vrPpTbclNsStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the vrPpTbclNs tables.

vrPpTbclNsIndex.name: vrPpTbclNsIndex
vrPpTbclNsIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the vrPpTbclNs tables.

vrPpTbclNsProvTable.name: vrPpTbclNsProvTable
vrPpTbclNsProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes associated with Ns. These attributes influence the application of filters to incoming and outgoing frames.

vrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter.name: vrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter
vrPpTbclNsIncomingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the incoming filter point.

vrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter.name: vrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter
vrPpTbclNsOutgoingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the out going filter point.

vrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable.name: vrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable
vrPpFddiETBRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of vrPpFddiETB components.

vrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry.name: vrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry
vrPpFddiETBRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single vrPpFddiETB component.

vrPpFddiETBRowStatus.name: vrPpFddiETBRowStatus
vrPpFddiETBRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of vrPpFddiETB components. These components can be added and deleted.

vrPpFddiETBComponentName.name: vrPpFddiETBComponentName
vrPpFddiETBComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

vrPpFddiETBStorageType.name: vrPpFddiETBStorageType
vrPpFddiETBStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the vrPpFddiETB tables.

vrPpFddiETBIndex.name: vrPpFddiETBIndex
vrPpFddiETBIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the vrPpFddiETB tables.

vrPpFddiETBProvTable.name: vrPpFddiETBProvTable
vrPpFddiETBProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx.name: vrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx
vrPpFddiETBTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

vrPpFddiETBFragmentIp.name: vrPpFddiETBFragmentIp
vrPpFddiETBFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

vrPpFddiETBServiceClass.name: vrPpFddiETBServiceClass
vrPpFddiETBServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

vrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress.name: vrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress
vrPpFddiETBConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

vrPpFddiETBPortNum.name: vrPpFddiETBPortNum
vrPpFddiETBPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

vrPpFddiETBOutboundFrameMediaType.name: vrPpFddiETBOutboundFrameMediaType
vrPpFddiETBOutboundFrameMediaType.description: This attribute specifies the media type the frame must be in before it is to be forwarded over the outbound supported WAN Bridge Protocol Port. The attribute only applies to outbound Bridge Protocol Port. For supported bridge ports, if the attribute value remains set to the default value of unaltered then there will be no frame conversion. When the value is set to the value ethernetConv then all frames being forwarded out the outbound WAN Port will be converted to ethernet before forwarding takes place. The only outbound WAN medias that currently support conversion are: FR (Frame Relay) and VNS. All other medias will fail the Bridge Port semantic check when attempts are made to alter this attribute. The following is an example of what the user may be able to do. Frames originating from a Token Ring are to be flooded out onto another Token Ring and a Frame Relay Port. The token ring Outbound port performs no translation, yet the FR Port has the outboundFrameMediaType attribute set to ethernetConv which results in the frame being translated into Ethernet format from Token Ring format before Frame Relay does its encapsulation and transmits over the FR port.

vrPpFddiETBTbProvTable.name: vrPpFddiETBTbProvTable
vrPpFddiETBTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

vrPpFddiETBSecureOption.name: vrPpFddiETBSecureOption
vrPpFddiETBSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

vrPpFddiETBStpProvTable.name: vrPpFddiETBStpProvTable
vrPpFddiETBStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

vrPpFddiETBAdminStatus.name: vrPpFddiETBAdminStatus
vrPpFddiETBAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

vrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl.name: vrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl
vrPpFddiETBPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

vrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv.name: vrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv
vrPpFddiETBStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

vrPpFddiETBPortPriority.name: vrPpFddiETBPortPriority
vrPpFddiETBPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

vrPpFddiETBPathCost.name: vrPpFddiETBPathCost
vrPpFddiETBPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

vrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod.name: vrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod
vrPpFddiETBPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

vrPpFddiETBDIProvTable.name: vrPpFddiETBDIProvTable
vrPpFddiETBDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBDomainNum.name: vrPpFddiETBDomainNum
vrPpFddiETBDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

vrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain.name: vrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain
vrPpFddiETBPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

vrPpFddiETBStateTable.name: vrPpFddiETBStateTable
vrPpFddiETBStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

vrPpFddiETBAdminState.name: vrPpFddiETBAdminState
vrPpFddiETBAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

vrPpFddiETBOperationalState.name: vrPpFddiETBOperationalState
vrPpFddiETBOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

vrPpFddiETBUsageState.name: vrPpFddiETBUsageState
vrPpFddiETBUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

vrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable.name: vrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable
vrPpFddiETBOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

vrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus.name: vrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus
vrPpFddiETBSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

vrPpFddiETBOperTable.name: vrPpFddiETBOperTable
vrPpFddiETBOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBPortName.name: vrPpFddiETBPortName
vrPpFddiETBPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

vrPpFddiETBUpTime.name: vrPpFddiETBUpTime
vrPpFddiETBUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpFddiETBDownTime.name: vrPpFddiETBDownTime
vrPpFddiETBDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpFddiETBBridgingMode.name: vrPpFddiETBBridgingMode
vrPpFddiETBBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

vrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig.name: vrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig
vrPpFddiETBBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

vrPpFddiETBBridgePortType.name: vrPpFddiETBBridgePortType
vrPpFddiETBBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBIfIndex.name: vrPpFddiETBIfIndex
vrPpFddiETBIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

vrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards
vrPpFddiETBDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

vrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards
vrPpFddiETBMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

vrPpFddiETBTbOperTable.name: vrPpFddiETBTbOperTable
vrPpFddiETBTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

vrPpFddiETBMaxInfo.name: vrPpFddiETBMaxInfo
vrPpFddiETBMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

vrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards
vrPpFddiETBBadVerifyDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because: a) the value of the secureOption attribute was set to on and b) it is not allowed to receive frames originating from the mac address found in the source address field of the frame (source mac address look up in the forwarding table failed.) on this bridge port. c) for the destination mac address found in the frame, the port the frame was received on does not appear as in port in the corresponding static table entry. Permission to receive frames from a mac address is granted via the static table entries. This attribute, badVerifyDiscards, is directly influenced by: 1. secureOption and 2. the static table entries. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches.name: vrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches
vrPpFddiETBUnicastNoMatches.description: This attribute is indicative of the number frames discarded because the MAC address found in the destination field did not match the local MAC address of the bridge port. This counter is only applicable for the protocols that are being routed currently.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards
vrPpFddiETBStaticEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because of the following two reasons: a) there was no entry for the 'allowed to go' field in the static table entry, where the input port is this bridge port. b) for spanning tree bpdus that are locally processed. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. It might prove useful to check the static table entry corresponding to the bridge port in question, if this counter consistently displays a high value. Ideally this counter should be as low as possible.

vrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards
vrPpFddiETBDynamicEntryDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that a) were discarded because of the fact that the bridge port, the frame is to go out of matches the bridge port it came in from or b) if the stp port state of the out port is not forwarding. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards
vrPpFddiETBLearningDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded while this bridge port was in a state other than the forwarding state. While in learning state the frame is discarded after the information from its header is learnt. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBInDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBInDiscards
vrPpFddiETBInDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were received by this bridge port and were discarded by the forwarding process. This includes frames that could have been discarded due to filtering. A repidly increasing value for this attribute could indicate a shrtage of resource in terms of memory needed to process the incoming frames. More memory can be provisioned through the VirtualRouter's memory manager.

vrPpFddiETBInFrames.name: vrPpFddiETBInFrames
vrPpFddiETBInFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been received by this port from its segment. Note that a frame received on this bridge port is counted if and only if it can be processed by the bridge logic contained in this bridge unit, a protocol that can be processed by the bridge logic. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBOutFrames.name: vrPpFddiETBOutFrames
vrPpFddiETBOutFrames.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that have been transmitted out this bridge port. Note that frame transmitted out this bridge port is counted if and only if it is for a protocol being processed by the bridge unit. This also includes management frames.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBStpOperTable.name: vrPpFddiETBStpOperTable
vrPpFddiETBStpOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes reflect the state of the bridge port's participation in the spanning tree protocol.

vrPpFddiETBStpPortState.name: vrPpFddiETBStpPortState
vrPpFddiETBStpPortState.description: This attribute specifies the spanning tree protocol state of the bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper.name: vrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper
vrPpFddiETBStpTypeOper.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol.

vrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost.name: vrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost
vrPpFddiETBDesignatedCost.description: This attribute specifies the path cost of the designated port of the lan segment connected to the port.

vrPpFddiETBPathCostOper.name: vrPpFddiETBPathCostOper
vrPpFddiETBPathCostOper.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. This attribute pathCostOper will track the value of the attribute pathCostProv when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set of off.

vrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge.name: vrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge
vrPpFddiETBDesignatedBridge.description: This attribute specifies the identifier of the bridge that this port considers to be the designated bridge.

vrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort.name: vrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort
vrPpFddiETBDesignatedPort.description: This attribute specifies the port identifier of the port on the designated bridge, attached to the same lan as this port is attached to.

vrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions.name: vrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions
vrPpFddiETBForwardTransitions.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of times this bridge port transitioned from the learning state to the forwarding state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. A rapidly increasing value might be indicative of an unstable spanning tree topology.

vrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards
vrPpFddiETBBlockingDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of incoming frames that were discarded because the bridge port was in the blocking state. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot.name: vrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot
vrPpFddiETBDesignatedRoot.description: This attribute specifies the bridge identifier of the bridge recorded as the root bridge, in the configuration BPDUs sent out by the designated bridge on the segment to which the port is attached.

vrPpFddiETBStatsTable.name: vrPpFddiETBStatsTable
vrPpFddiETBStatsTable.description: This group houses all the statistical attributes applicable to all types of bridge ports and represents the common factor between them. These attributes in part reflect the state of the bridge port.

vrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards
vrPpFddiETBBadAbstractDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the data that was abstracted, from frames coming in through this bridge port, did not conform to the format expected by the bridge logic.This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn.name: vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn
vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesIn.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames received on this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut.name: vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut
vrPpFddiETBTinygramFramesOut.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames transmitted out this bridge port that used the tinygram compression scheme.

vrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards
vrPpFddiETBInFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the in filter point. This includes a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the in filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the in filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards.name: vrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards
vrPpFddiETBOutFilterDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded at the out filter point. This includes: a) frames discarded due to application of the filter defined with PCF for the out filter point and b) the frames discarded due to domain based filtering at the out filter point. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295.

vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable.name: vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable
vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of vrPpFddiETBNs components.

vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry.name: vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry
vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single vrPpFddiETBNs component.

vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus.name: vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus
vrPpFddiETBNsRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of vrPpFddiETBNs components. These components can be added and deleted.

vrPpFddiETBNsComponentName.name: vrPpFddiETBNsComponentName
vrPpFddiETBNsComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

vrPpFddiETBNsStorageType.name: vrPpFddiETBNsStorageType
vrPpFddiETBNsStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the vrPpFddiETBNs tables.

vrPpFddiETBNsIndex.name: vrPpFddiETBNsIndex
vrPpFddiETBNsIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the vrPpFddiETBNs tables.

vrPpFddiETBNsProvTable.name: vrPpFddiETBNsProvTable
vrPpFddiETBNsProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes associated with Ns. These attributes influence the application of filters to incoming and outgoing frames.

vrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter.name: vrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter
vrPpFddiETBNsIncomingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the incoming filter point.

vrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter.name: vrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter
vrPpFddiETBNsOutgoingFilter.description: This attribute specifies the name of the filter to be applied at the out going filter point.

vrPpTbpRowStatusTable.name: vrPpTbpRowStatusTable
vrPpTbpRowStatusTable.description: This entry controls the addition and deletion of vrPpTbp components.

vrPpTbpRowStatusEntry.name: vrPpTbpRowStatusEntry
vrPpTbpRowStatusEntry.description: A single entry in the table represents a single vrPpTbp component.

vrPpTbpRowStatus.name: vrPpTbpRowStatus
vrPpTbpRowStatus.description: This variable is used as the basis for SNMP naming of vrPpTbp components. These components can be added and deleted.

vrPpTbpComponentName.name: vrPpTbpComponentName
vrPpTbpComponentName.description: This variable provides the component's string name for use with the ASCII Console Interface

vrPpTbpStorageType.name: vrPpTbpStorageType
vrPpTbpStorageType.description: This variable represents the storage type value for the vrPpTbp tables.

vrPpTbpIndex.name: vrPpTbpIndex
vrPpTbpIndex.description: This variable represents the index for the vrPpTbp tables.

vrPpTbpProvTable.name: vrPpTbpProvTable
vrPpTbpProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable attributes that belong to the this group. This group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes influence the working of a bridge port.

vrPpTbpTranslateIpx.name: vrPpTbpTranslateIpx
vrPpTbpTranslateIpx.description: This attribute specifies the type of translation to be performed on frames carrying IPX packets. Ethernet frames carrying IPX payload could be translated to IEEE 802.3 frames (with the same IPX payload) or vice- versa. The main reason to do so is to allow the bridge unit to consistently forward one type of frames carrying IPX packets. Translations can be turned off altogether in which case the IPX frames will pass through the bridge unit unchanged.

vrPpTbpFragmentIp.name: vrPpTbpFragmentIp
vrPpTbpFragmentIp.description: This attribute specifies if or not outbound frames carrying IP datagrams should be fragmented to conform to message transfer unit (mtu) sizes dictated by the media.

vrPpTbpServiceClass.name: vrPpTbpServiceClass
vrPpTbpServiceClass.description: This attribute specifies if the frames should be ordered or not before they are transmitted through a bridge port. If this attribute has a value of ordered the received frames are ordered as in the original message, before they are transmitted out through a bridge port. If it has a value of notOrdered, received then frames pass through the bridge unit in the order they are received. This feature can be used over multiple telecommunication links to increase data flow. Please note that this attribute only affects link protocols and is ineffective with lan media.

vrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress.name: vrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress
vrPpTbpConvertArpMacAddress.description: This attribute is indicative of the state of the MAC address format conversion process for ARP/RARP frames. The MAC addresses may be translated if need be from a canonical format to a non-canonical format, based on the needs of the associated media. If this attribute is set to a value of on then all Mac addresses will converted if need be to suit the format of mac address, the outgoing media will support. If this attribute is set to a value of off no such conversion takes place.

vrPpTbpPortNum.name: vrPpTbpPortNum
vrPpTbpPortNum.description: This attribute is indicative of the unique number assigned to the bridge port. It is used for SNMP management of this bridge port and in spanning tree as an identifier this bridge port. Notes regarding portNum: Escape routines exist for initializing, copying, and deleting port numbers. This is necessary because SNMP requires a unique port instance identifier. The initPortNum escape routine sets the port number to a value in the range 1-255 for this purpose. The setCopiedPortNum escape routine exists to maintain the uniqueness of the port number in cases when one port is copied to another. When a bridge port is deleted, the releasePortNum escape routine places the port number being released into a pending deletion state. This is because the port number cannot be re-allocated until the port is truely deleted in the current view. This is necessary since there is no guarantee of order when processing changes to multiple protocol ports so without the pending deletion state, the same port number could be temporarily assigned to two ports for a short period of time. The portNum is set as component critical since bridging also uses the port number as a key for indexing into its data structures. If a port is deleted then re-added under the same protocol port, CAS treats the change as a SET to the portNum attribute.

vrPpTbpOutboundFrameMediaType.name: vrPpTbpOutboundFrameMediaType
vrPpTbpOutboundFrameMediaType.description: This attribute specifies the media type the frame must be in before it is to be forwarded over the outbound supported WAN Bridge Protocol Port. The attribute only applies to outbound Bridge Protocol Port. For supported bridge ports, if the attribute value remains set to the default value of unaltered then there will be no frame conversion. When the value is set to the value ethernetConv then all frames being forwarded out the outbound WAN Port will be converted to ethernet before forwarding takes place. The only outbound WAN medias that currently support conversion are: FR (Frame Relay) and VNS. All other medias will fail the Bridge Port semantic check when attempts are made to alter this attribute. The following is an example of what the user may be able to do. Frames originating from a Token Ring are to be flooded out onto another Token Ring and a Frame Relay Port. The token ring Outbound port performs no translation, yet the FR Port has the outboundFrameMediaType attribute set to ethernetConv which results in the frame being translated into Ethernet format from Token Ring format before Frame Relay does its encapsulation and transmits over the FR port.

vrPpTbpTbProvTable.name: vrPpTbpTbProvTable
vrPpTbpTbProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes in part influence the working of a bridge port operating in the TB mode.

vrPpTbpSecureOption.name: vrPpTbpSecureOption
vrPpTbpSecureOption.description: This attribute specifies whether the port secure feature is enabled. The secure feature, if enabled causes the following things to happen: a) disallows dynamic learning, b) disallows frames to be forwarded that do not satisfy the following condition: the mac address of the source should be found in the forwarding table and the destination mac address of the frame should also be found in the forwarding table. In addition to this, the port the frame was received on should figure as the in port, given the destination mac address found in the frame. c) disallows frames to be forwarded if the allowed to go port map for the destination mac address is empty. This feature in effect allows the user to choose the hosts that can generate traffic and the hosts that can receive traffic through this bridge unit.

vrPpTbpStpProvTable.name: vrPpTbpStpProvTable
vrPpTbpStpProvTable.description: This group houses all the port specific provisionable attributes that belong to the Stp group. The Stp group is applicable to all the bridge ports that participate in the spanning tree protocol. These attributes influence the participation of the bridge port in the spanning tree protocol.

vrPpTbpAdminStatus.name: vrPpTbpAdminStatus
vrPpTbpAdminStatus.description: This attribute defines the current administrative state for this component. enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. disabled indicates the component is unavailable for operation.

vrPpTbpPortStateStpControl.name: vrPpTbpPortStateStpControl
vrPpTbpPortStateStpControl.description: This attribute specifies whether or not spanning tree protocol state for this bridge port is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. In essence it indicates the participation of this bridge port in the spanning tree protocol, by accepting and acting on received bridge protocol data units and by sending out the same. on signifies that this bridge port's spanning tree port state is controlled by the spanning tree protocol. A value of off signifies that the spanning tree port state of this bridge port is unaffected by the spanning tree protocol. This in effect puts the bridge port out of reach of the spanning tree protocol and in the forwarding state. Care should be taken while assigning a value of off to this attribute, as this might cause network loops. Please do not set this attribute to off unless you are absolutely sure about the effect of such an action on your network topology.

vrPpTbpStpTypeProv.name: vrPpTbpStpTypeProv
vrPpTbpStpTypeProv.description: This attribute specifies the type of spanning tree protocol the port is participating in. A bridge port could participate in either the ieee8021 spanning tree protocol or the dec spanning tree protocol. If the value of the attribute protocolSpec in the SpanningTreeProtocol component, provisioned under the TransparentBridge component is in conflict with the value of this attribute, the value of the protocolSpec attribute will prevail. Prevailing stp type is reflected in the value of the attribute stpTypeOper.

vrPpTbpPortPriority.name: vrPpTbpPortPriority
vrPpTbpPortPriority.description: This attribute specifies the value for port priority, which is contained in the first octet of the port identifier. Valid values are as follows: 1) 0..255 for stp type DEC and 2) 0..65535 for stp type IEEE.

vrPpTbpPathCost.name: vrPpTbpPathCost
vrPpTbpPathCost.description: This attribute specifies the contribution of this port, to all the paths to the root bridge that include this port. Please note that the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is applied only when the value of the attribute pathCostMethod is set to on and is ignored if otherwise.

vrPpTbpPathCostMethod.name: vrPpTbpPathCostMethod
vrPpTbpPathCostMethod.description: This attribute specifies the method used by the bridging logic, to calculate the path cost to the bridge considered to be the root bridge in the spanning tree topology. This attribute should be set to off before attempting to provision a value for pathCostProv.

vrPpTbpDIProvTable.name: vrPpTbpDIProvTable
vrPpTbpDIProvTable.description: This group houses all the provisionable, domain specific attributes for a non-encapsulating bridge port.

vrPpTbpDomainNum.name: vrPpTbpDomainNum
vrPpTbpDomainNum.description: This attribute specifies the domain number associated with this bridge port. Domain numbers are used for confining frames to a domain. Domain based filtering provides a complete segregation of traffic based on domain number associated with frames. There can exist only sixteen domains when a spanning tree is desired specific to each domain. When there is only a single spanning tree spanning all the domains the maximum number of domains possible are 4294967293. This attribute is of no relevance when associated with backbone bridge port. Its value is ignored in such a situation.

vrPpTbpPreserveDomain.name: vrPpTbpPreserveDomain
vrPpTbpPreserveDomain.description: This attribute specifies if the domain information should be preserved or embedded in the frame header. This attribute applies only to backbone ports and does not affect the access bridge ports. By setting this attribute to a value of on, domain information could be preserved in frames being tunnelled across the a backbone, so that this information can be deciphered at the other end of the backbone tunnel. This preserves the integrity of the domains thus preventing domain breaches while tunnelling frames across backbone network. If the value of this attribute is set to off then domain information is not preserved in the header of the frames tunnelling through the backbone. This eliminates the overhead incurred to preserve domain information across the backbone while tunnelling frames across it. Preserve domain is relevant when used in conjunction with the following media: FDDI, ATM MPE, Frame Relay and PPP. It is ignored when used with other types of media.

vrPpTbpStateTable.name: vrPpTbpStateTable
vrPpTbpStateTable.description: This group contains the three OSI State attributes. The descriptions generically indicate what each state attribute implies about the component. Note that not all the values and state combinations described here are supported by every component which uses this group. For component-specific information and the valid state combinations, refer to NTP 241-7001-150, Passport Operations and Maintenance Guide.

vrPpTbpAdminState.name: vrPpTbpAdminState
vrPpTbpAdminState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Administrative State of the component. The value locked indicates that the component is administratively prohibited from providing services for its users. A Lock or Lock - force command has been previously issued for this component. When the value is locked, the value of usageState must be idle. The value shuttingDown indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide service to its existing users only. A Lock command was issued against the component and it is in the process of shutting down. The value unlocked indicates that the component is administratively permitted to provide services for its users. To enter this state, issue an Unlock command to this component.

vrPpTbpOperationalState.name: vrPpTbpOperationalState
vrPpTbpOperationalState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Operational State of the component. The value enabled indicates that the component is available for operation. Note that if adminState is locked, it would still not be providing service. The value disabled indicates that the component is not available for operation. For example, something is wrong with the component itself, or with another component on which this one depends. If the value is disabled, the usageState must be idle.

vrPpTbpUsageState.name: vrPpTbpUsageState
vrPpTbpUsageState.description: This attribute indicates the OSI Usage State of the component. The value idle indicates that the component is not currently in use. The value active indicates that the component is in use and has spare capacity to provide for additional users. The value busy indicates that the component is in use and has no spare operating capacity for additional users at this time.

vrPpTbpOperStatusTable.name: vrPpTbpOperStatusTable
vrPpTbpOperStatusTable.description: This group includes the Operational Status attribute. This attribute defines the current operational state of this component.

vrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus.name: vrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus
vrPpTbpSnmpOperStatus.description: The current state of the interface. The up state indicates the interface is operational and capable of forwarding packets. The down state indicates the interface is not operational, thus unable to forward packets. testing state indicates that no operational packets can be passed.

vrPpTbpOperTable.name: vrPpTbpOperTable
vrPpTbpOperTable.description: This group houses all the operational attributes belonging to the base group. The base group of attributes is applicable to all types of bridge ports and represent the common factor between them. These attributes in part, reflect the state of a bridge port.

vrPpTbpPortName.name: vrPpTbpPortName
vrPpTbpPortName.description: The attribute portName is a string of the form 'BridgePortName-i', where BridgePortName is the abbreviation of the corresponding bridge port and i is the instance identifier of the ProtocolPort, the bridge port is provisioned under. For example a TransparentBridgePort provisioned under ProtocolPort/myport would have a name TBP-myport.

vrPpTbpUpTime.name: vrPpTbpUpTime
vrPpTbpUpTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated up time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpTbpDownTime.name: vrPpTbpDownTime
vrPpTbpDownTime.description: This attribute specifies the accumulated down time of this bridge port since the last reset occurred.

vrPpTbpBridgingMode.name: vrPpTbpBridgingMode
vrPpTbpBridgingMode.description: This attribute specifies the mode of bridging this port can support. It in turn implies the format of frames, this bridge port can process and forward.

vrPpTbpBridgePortConfig.name: vrPpTbpBridgePortConfig
vrPpTbpBridgePortConfig.description: This attribute specifies the bridge port's configuration. It indicates if the bridge port is operating as an access port or as a backbone port. An access bridge port does not encapsulate a MAC frame and does not preserve domain information in the encapsulation, whereas a backbone bridge port encapsulates the MAC frame and optionally preserves domain information in the encapsulated frame.A backbone bridge port is typically used to transport frames across a high bandwidth backbone network to another bridge unit for further processing/forwarding of the frame.

vrPpTbpBridgePortType.name: vrPpTbpBridgePortType
vrPpTbpBridgePortType.description: This attribute specifies the type of bridge port that was provisioned. It takes into consideration the bridgingMode, bridgePortConfig and the media the bridge port is linked to before branding a bridge port.

vrPpTbpIfIndex.name: vrPpTbpIfIndex
vrPpTbpIfIndex.description: This attribute specifies the index into the Interface Table where in information about the media interface corresponding to the bridge port is maintained.

vrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards.name: vrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards
vrPpTbpDelayExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames that were discarded because the time taken to process these frames exceeded the transit delay allowed for this bridge unit. This attribute is not supported by bridging and will always have a value of 0.

vrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards.name: vrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards
vrPpTbpMtuExceededDiscards.description: This attribute is indicative of the number of frames discarded because the size of the out bound frame exceeded the message transfer unit (mtu) allowed for the bridge port. Note that this counter only refers to the outbound frames for this bridge port. This counter wraps around its maximum value of 4294967295. This counter is influenced by the attribute fragmentIp. This counter is incremented when the a frame larger than the mtu allowed is encountered and cannot be fragmented. If this counter is increasing steadily, it might be useful to set the value of the attribute fragmentIp to a value of on.

vrPpTbpTbOperTable.name: vrPpTbpTbOperTable
vrPpTbpTbOperTable.description: This group houses all the port specific operational attributes that belong to the Tb group. This group also houses all the port specific statistical attributes that belong to the Tb group. The Tb group is only applicable bridge port types that operate in the TB mode. These attributes reflect the state of a bridge port operating in the TB mode

vrPpTbpMaxInfo.name: vrPpTbpMaxInfo
vrPpTbpMaxInfo.description: This attribute specifies the maximum size of the information field in a TB frame. This excludes the header field.

vrPpTbpBadVerifyDiscards.name: vrPpTbpBadVerifyDiscards
